items.title: Incompatibility with django logging of queries.
items.body:
Hello, 

I have noticed in version 2.0.1 that I had the same problem of queries logged as «None» in Django,  as in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54574499/django-logging-django-db-backends-returns-0-000-none-args-none-message

I fixed the logging problem by downgrading mysqlclient as well. I had the 1.4.6 before

I'm using pip 20.1.1

django is 1.11.6 ( i know, old )

And this is on python docker image with the tag ` python:3.5`

which I know is old

I don't have much more detail for now. Thanks a lot to all of you contributors. 
I can help for the review later on if it happens.

items.title: error: ssl_mode not supported by client library
items.body:
### Describe the bug

I get an error trying to specify `ssl_mode`

### To Reproduce

```py
from MySQLdb import _mysql
_mysql.connect(user='root', passwd='password', ssl_mode='REQUIRED')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
MySQLdb._exceptions.NotSupportedError: MySQL client library does not support ssl_mode specification
```

### Environment

**MySQL Client**

- OS: Windows 10

- Python: Python 3.8.3 (vanilla install via Scoop)

- Connector/C (e.g. Homebrew mysql-client 8.0.18): mysqlclient 2.0.1 (installed via `pip`)
```
>>> get_client_info()
'10.4.3'
```

items.title: Doesn't build on Windows
items.body:
### Describe the bug

When I attempt to build on Windows (either `pip install mysqlclient` in a virtualenv or by cloning this Git repo and running `python setup.py bdist_wheel`), I get the following error:

`MySQLdb/_mysql.c(29): fatal error C1083: Cannot open include file: 'mysql.h': No such file or directory`

I have both the MySQL Connector/C 6.1.11 (from the archive) and MariaDB Connector/C 3.1.8 installed. However the paths in `site.cfg` and `setup_windows.py` are contradictory and so it finds neither. If I edit `setup_windows.py` and change `client` to `mysqlclient`, it builds correctly. With `client` set to `mariadbclient` I was also able to get it to work, but I had to change `connector` in `site.cfg` to `C:\Program Files (x86)\MariaDB\MariaDB Connector C` and remove `"mariadb"` from the end of the `library_dirs` and `include_dirs`. I would think that if the `connector` path is set to MySQL Connector/C 6.1, then the `client` should be set to `mysqlclient` so that it at least might build for someone who has the correct packages installed.

I realize building on Windows is hard, but the advice "Building mysqlclient on Windows is very hard. But there are some binary wheels you can install easily." is unhelpful if there aren't wheels for your platform and there's no information at all about how to build your own wheel. Specifically, there are no 32-bit (x86) wheels, only x64 wheels, on PyPI and I'm running the x86 version of Python 3.7. I was able to find [unofficial wheels](https://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/#mysqlclient), but I would rather not reference that in my requirements file. Having official x86 wheels on PyPI would be the best resolution. But also, it would be nice if there were at least a chance it could build if I had the right packages installed, and at least some documentation of what to install. Is there some connector that could be installed to make it build as-is, or are those paths designed for a custom layout on the machine where the official wheels are built?

Since it does seem to build with multiple connectors, It would be nice if it could search for a suitable connector installed out of the few known to work options and use the first available. Before I go and do the work, would you accept a pull request where I attempt to do this?

### Environment

**MySQL Server**

- Server OS: Windows 10
- Server Version: MySQL 5.7.30

**MySQL Client**

- OS: Windows 10

- Python: CPython 3.7.3 x86

items.title: installer must check prerequisites before installing
items.body:
### Describe bug

When running the installer, if prerequisites like the Python and MySQL development headers and libraries are not already installed, the installer fails with cryptic messages that are unclear to some users.

### To Reproduce

**Shell**

```sh
pip install mysqlclient
```

### Environment

**MySQL Client**

- OS (e.g. Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04): Any

- Python (e.g. Homebrew Python 3.7.5): Any

- Connector/C (e.g. Homebrew mysql-client 8.0.18): Any


### Additional context

I've seen other installers perform checks to ensure the prerequisites are installed before running the compiler.  If prerequisites aren't available, then the installer gives clear, plain-English messages stating what needs to be installed before this installer can continue.  That avoids confusion caused by cryptic messages from the compiler.

items.title: Request: Rename class name from MySQLdb to mysqlclient
items.body:
### Describe the request

Generally when importing most packages in python, the import name is similar or the same as the pkg name. This has come up in one situation when I use ```pipreqs``` to create a ```requirements.txt``` file. When ```pipreqs``` is run, it cannot find mysqlclient pkg because it uses the import name in the python file to search for the package:
```
$ pipreqs . --print --debug
DEBUG: Found packages: {'MySQLdb'}
DEBUG: Found imports: MySQLdb
DEBUG: Getting packages information from Local/PyPI
DEBUG: Starting new HTTPS connection (1): pypi.python.org:443
DEBUG: https://pypi.python.org:443 "GET /pypi/MySQLdb/json HTTP/1.1" 301 122
DEBUG: Starting new HTTPS connection (1): pypi.org:443
DEBUG: https://pypi.org:443 "GET /pypi/MySQLdb/json HTTP/1.1" 404 152
DEBUG: Package MySQLdb does not exist or network problems
INFO: Successfully output requirements
```
### To Reproduce

run ```pipreqs .``` in the directory of package using mysqlclient/MySQLdb.

### Environment
```
$ pipreqs --version
0.4.10
```
- OS: xubuntu 16.10
- Python version: 3.8.1 
- mysqlclient version: 1.4.6

### Additional context
This is a request not abug report..

items.title: Character set errors when using mysqlclient 1.4.4 and above
items.body:
Hi

We've been using mysqlclient 1.3.14 with Django 2.2.9 and MySQL 5.7.21 enterprise with encrypted databases (all on Centos 7 using Python 3.6.8) for some time. Our database and tables use utf8mb4 throughout. When we upgrade to using mysqlclient 1.4.6 in our test environment we can no longer enter emojis into text fields through the Django web application. The MySQL error being generated by our test suite is:

MySQLdb._exceptions.OperationalError: (1366, "Incorrect string value: '\\xF0\\x9F\\x98\\x8A.' for column 'some_field' at row 1")

We have also tested this in the browser (i.e. separately from our test suite) using the web application and have confirmed that text containing an emoji is rejected with a MySQL error. 

If we downgrade mysqlclient to 1.4.3 the data is inserted correctly (into the same database that previously rejected the insert), if we update to 1.4.4 then the error appears again (as before, using the exact same database). If we go back to 1.3.14 (as we currently use) then the data can also be inserted. In each case we are not making code changes other than installing different versions of mysqlclient using pip. Our application has had support for emojis etc for several years.

As far as we can tell, with no other code changes, the error is only occurring once we start using mysqlclient 1.4.4 and above. The changelog shows that the way charsets were being handled in connections changed with 1.4.4. We're wondering if this has caused an issue, possibly with connections to encrypted MySQL databases falling back to a default charset for some reason? We are specifying 'utf8mb4' as the charset used in the DATABASES settings in Django and this is an existing application that has not experienced similar errors before. If the connection is falling back to the default charset (i.e. not 'utf8mb4') then this is the error we would expect to see.

Any help/suggestions would be gratefully received.

Cheers

Kieren

**MySQL Server**

- Server OS: Centos 7
- Server Version: MySQL 5.7.21-enterprise

**MySQL Client**

- OS: Centos 7
- Python: Python 3.6.8
- Connector/C: mysqlclient 1.3.14 - 1.4.3 are fine, 1.4.4 and above result in errors

Application uses Django 2.2.9

items.title: Result set created by calling stored procedure causes error after upgrading from 1.3.5
items.body:
**Note:** If you wanted, I would be happy to (attempt to) contribute a fix for this.

### Describe the bug

Calling `callproc` twice without calling `nextset` in between causes error, even when `fetchall` is used. Seen after upgrading from 1.3.5 => 1.4.6 (also seen on 1.3.13).

### To Reproduce

**Schema**

Doesn't matter, just create a proc like:

```
create procedure foo() select 1;
```

**Code**

```py
from django.db import connection
c = connection.cursor()
c.callproc('foo')
c.fetchall()
c.callproc('foo')
```

This will raise `MySQLdb._exceptions.ProgrammingError: (2014, "Commands out of sync; you can't run this command now")`

### Environment

**MySQL Server**

- Server OS (e.g. Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04): macOS 10.12.6
- Server Version (e.g. MariaDB 10.3.16): mysql  Ver 14.14 Distrib 5.7.25, for osx10.12 (x86_64) using  EditLine wrapper

**MySQL Client**

- OS (e.g. Windows 10, Ubuntu 20.04): macOS 10.12.6

- Python (e.g. Homebrew Python 3.7.5): Python 3.7.4

- Connector/C (e.g. Homebrew mysql-client 8.0.18): `pip install mysqlclient==1.4.6` (same behavior on 1.3.13)


### Additional context

I often call multiple procedures using this method and it needing to update every wrapper function to call `nextset` is a hassle. This is also causes issues for future development as it's not an easy issue to debug if you aren't already aware of it.

For example, we write Python functions to wrap all our procedures. If a dev were to call two of these within a request and `nextset` was missing from one, it would be very difficult for them to figure out what was wrong. In my opinion this makes `callproc` unsafe and we would have to patch it ourselves if it's not fixed here.

I did eventually find a note in the [docs](https://mysqlclient.readthedocs.io/user_guide.html#cursor-objects) about this but to me this seems like a regression and unexpected behavior.

Thank you!

items.title: Binary wheel for Python 3.8 for Windows
items.body:
## Problem description
There is no binary wheel for CPython 3.8 for Windows on PyPI: <https://pypi.org/project/mysqlclient/#files>.

## Steps to reproduce
1. Install [Python](https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/) 3.8.
2. Run:
~~~
py -3.8 -m pip install mysqlclient --only-binary=mysqlclient 
~~~
### Actual result
~~~
C:\Users\user\Desktop>py -3.8 -m pip install mysqlclient --only-binary=mysqlclient
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement mysqlclient (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for mysqlclient
~~~
### Expected result
No errors.

items.title: Characters in the \x80 - \x9f range not returning as expected
items.body:
I’m trying to retrieve data from a MySQL v5.1 database in which most of the character settings are latin1.  The trouble is with characters in the \x80 - \x9f range, the ones that are different between canonical latin1 (ISO-8859-1) and MySQL’s latin1 (cp1252).  I’m using mysqlclient as part of a Django application but I’ve tried to replicate the problem with a more direct example below.  The replication isn’t perfect, the Django application throws an error: "'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0x92 in position 5: invalid start byte" when there is no charset option set.  It prints "Women . s" (i.e. whitespace in place of the apostrophe) when the `charset = 'latin1'` option is provided.  However, I hope the example below is close enough that the solution will work for Django as well.

In the example below, the word "Women’s", with the apostrophe as \x92, is being stored in a MySQL v5.7 database.

First, set up a local MySQL v5.7 server so it's similar to the MySQL v5.1 server that we're trying to hit.
```
mysql> CREATE DATABASE testchar;
mysql> USE testchar;
mysql> CREATE TABLE testchar (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, data_value VARCHAR(80) CHARACTER SET latin1 ) ENGINE=MYISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
mysql> INSERT INTO testchar(data_value) VALUES (UNHEX("576F6D656E9273"));
```

It looks ok with a CONVERT statement but not with a SELECT statement
```
mysql> SELECT CONVERT (UNHEX("576F6D656E9273") USING latin1);
+------------------------------------------------+
| CONVERT (UNHEX("576F6D656E9273") USING latin1) |
+------------------------------------------------+
| Women’s                                        |
+------------------------------------------------+

mysql> SELECT UNHEX("576F6D656E9273");
+-------------------------+
| UNHEX("576F6D656E9273") |
+-------------------------+
| Women?s                  |
+-------------------------+
```

Now set up the python environment
```
$ virtualenv -p python3.7 --no-site-packages venv
$ source venv/bin/activate
$ pip install mysqlclient

$ python
>>> import MySQLdb
>>> db = MySQLdb.connect(host="127.0.0.1", db="testchar", user="user", password="password")
>>> c = db.cursor()
>>> c.execute("show variables like 'char%';")
>>> c.fetchall()
```

Should see lots of utf-8 settings.  In order to simulate what is shown when this is done on the actual v5.1 server, need to set names.
```
>>> c.execute("set names latin1")
>>> c.execute("show variables like 'char%';")
>>> c.fetchall()
```

Should see the connection, result, and client values change to latin1.  This is close to what the v5.1 server is set to.

Now try the query
```
>>> c.execute("select * from testchar")
>>> c.fetchall()
((1, 'Women\x92s'),)
```

The same thing happens if I pass `charset="latin1"` to the `db.connect(...` statement.

Is there something I’m doing wrong in making this connection, or some setting I need to add to make this work as expected?  

I did try posting to Stack Overflow, and got a [response](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58384136/character-encoding-issue-when-using-python3-mysqlclient-to-retreive-data-encoded?answertab=active#tab-top), but the suggestions didn’t fix the problem.  Any suggestions you can provide would be great, thanks.

items.title: the "SET NAMES" change in mysqlclient 1.4.4 seems to break a case on MySQL 8.0
items.body:
So it's not clear if this is actually a regression, because apparently PyMySQL has had this problem for awhile, but it just popped up on mysqlclient 1.4.4.   Re-adding the "SET NAMES" mentioned in the changelog seems to fix it.   I think MySQL 8.0 has a problem when SET NAMES is not called so if pymysql/mysqlclient won't add it back in I will likely have to add it to SQLAlchemy.

Test case:

```
import MySQLdb

conn = MySQLdb.connect(
    user="scott", passwd="tiger", host="mysql80", db="test", charset="utf8mb4"
)

cursor = conn.cursor()
# uncomment to fix issue
#cursor.execute("SET NAMES utf8mb4")

for name in [
    "engineers",
    "managers",
]:
    cursor.execute("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS %s" % name)


cursor.execute(
    """
CREATE TABLE engineers (
    person_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (person_id)
)
"""
)

cursor.execute(
    """
CREATE TABLE managers (
    person_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
    manager_name VARCHAR(50),
    PRIMARY KEY (person_id)
)
"""
)

cursor.execute("""
    SELECT engineers.person_id, CAST(null AS CHAR(50)) AS manager_name
    FROM engineers
    UNION
    SELECT managers.person_id, managers.manager_name FROM managers
""")


print(cursor.fetchall())

```

this is using MySQL 8.0.16 running in Centos docker:

`MySQLdb._exceptions.OperationalError: (1271, "Illegal mix of collations for operation 'UNION'")
`

It doesn't like the "CAST(NULL AS CHAR(50))" in the UNION.    suddenly.   adding back the SET NAMES makes it go away.   only on MySQL 8, not on 5.7, 5.6, mariadb, etc.

Sorry this issue kind of sucks.

items.title: MR #346 breaks sphinxsearch connection
items.body:
MR #346 makes all string values returned from sphinxsearch connection via mysql protocol to be bytes.
Steps to reproduce:
```
# clone project
#> git clone https://github.com/tumb1er/django_sphinxsearch
#> cd django_sphinxsearch
# setup virtual env
#> virtualenv --python=python3.6 .
#> . bin/activate
# install requirements
#> pip install -r test-requires.txt
# start searchd with indices at /tmp
#> docker-compose up sphinxsearch 
# run tests
#> ./manage.py test
Ran 181 tests in 1.244s

OK
# update mysqlclient to MR 346
#> pip install git+git://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python.git@e04c5972f526805e7c310aa213d1eadbabb45371
# run tests again
#> ./manage.py test
AssertionError: b'another string' != 'another string' : attr_string

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 181 tests in 1.123s

FAILED (failures=47, errors=1)
```
It seems that every single string column is now broken.

I'm not sure that this is a bug of mysqlclient, but need help with getting strings back.

items.title: use_unicode respects FLAG_BINARY in 1.4.0
items.body: It appears that 3bea8cd8dd89c1d078a6ff2a36ef5804429f398f made `use_unicode` start not converting fields to Unicode that are returned with `BINARY_FLAG`. [Specifically](https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/commit/3bea8cd8dd89c1d078a6ff2a36ef5804429f398f#diff-1ae3b1bf2e25b3800993d7b9742c2b97R187), `_bytes_or_str` can return bytes whereas `_string_decode` never could. Was this behavior change intentional? 3bea8cd8dd89c1d078a6ff2a36ef5804429f398f looks like it was intended to be pure optimization.

No exception is raised.

An exception is raised:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
```

Removed `"NULL"` from `__all__` of `__init__.py`

#369

items.title: Cannot import _mysql_exceptions
items.body:
We have been using mysqlclient with Python3 for a long time - more precisely with Apache Airflow.
However, with release 1.4.0, _mysql and _mysql_exceptions was moved to MySQLdb in pull request #293. I cannot find any explanations for this move - but it breaks our code?
Airflow is Python3 only, and newer Airflow distributions (Docker/Kubernetes) includes 1.4.x instead of 1.3.x and breaks code depending on _mysql_exceptions.
We cannot install and use MySQLdb as it is Python2 only. Also, it would require modifications of the standard Airflow image.
This decision makes mysqlclient Python2 only as well in some regards - why?

items.body:
I'm getting lots of different varieties of this failure but the general idea seems to be that if deprecation warnings raise errors, MySQLdb can't run queries, Python 3.8.0b1:

```
import warnings
import MySQLdb

# remove this to eliminate errors
warnings.filterwarnings("error", category=DeprecationWarning)


conn = MySQLdb.connect(user="scott", password="tiger", host="localhost", db="test")
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("select 1")

```
output:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test3.py", line 9, in <module>
    cursor.execute("select 1")
  File "/home/classic/dev/sqlalchemy/.tox/py38-mysql/lib/python3.8/site-packages/MySQLdb/cursors.py", line 206, in execute

    _mysql.connection.query(self, query)
MySQLdb._exceptions.ProgrammingError: (1064, <NULL>)

```
If I try to use charset, I get something different (likely because it is tripping over a deprecation warning -> error somewhere else):

```
import warnings
import MySQLdb

warnings.filterwarnings("error", category=DeprecationWarning)


conn = MySQLdb.connect(user="scott", password="tiger", host="localhost", db="test", charset="utf8mb4")
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("select 1")

```

raises:

`MySQLdb._exceptions.ProgrammingError: (1064, 'You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MariaDB server version for the right syntax to use near \'H??t\'H??t"1?f\x0f\x1f?\' at line 1')
`

but what's weird is that it's not raising for a deprecation warning, so it looks like something is happening in the C code

items.title: Solution to the MacOS problem
items.body:
Took me a while to understand what the README meant when it said I should edit `mysql_config`. It means to edit the actual executable.

For future reference, this one-liner should fix it:
```
sudo sed -i '' 's/libs="$libs -l"/libs="$libs -lmysqlclient -lssl -lcrypto"/' $(which mysql_config)
```

items.title: Connection constructor not honoring column type -> custom conversion function (for JSON and other types)
items.body:
Hello - firstly, thank you so much for all your work in maintaining this client. I have been using various versions of this for over 10 years!

I have found a potential issue with Python3 and the new JSON datatype in MySQL > 5.7 ( I am using 8.0).

I wanted to add a converter to go from JSON -> Python dicts seamlessly by specifying a conv= option in the constructor and for the reads, we seem to be not honoring any of the passed in decoders.
This [`if use_unicode:` block](https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/master/MySQLdb/connections.py#L199) basically sets the JSON decoder to `unicode` always.

I worked around it by doing `conn.converter[MySQLdb.constants.FIELD_TYPE.JSON] = json_to_dict` after the constructor is called, but would be nice to honor the passed in conv object overrides after the use_unicode block.

items.title: Bug _mysql.c - binary flag?
items.body:
Hi,

Thanks for your effort providing us this driver.

However, I think there is a bug in _mysql.c. In the function "_mysql_field_to_python" there is a switch statement. In this statement the binary flag is always overwritten by the default block.
As a consequence I'm getting trouble processing binary data because the binary data is treated as text leading into conversion trouble.
I wanted to let you know about the problem, because you might want to check.

Thanks and regards!

items.title: Version 1.4.X and again KOI8-R encoding
items.body:
Hi.

In 1.3.X versions I had an issue #257 and solved it simply adding 
```python
        if charset == "utf8mb4":
            py_charset = "utf8"
        elif charset == "latin1":
            py_charset = 'koi8-r'
        else:
            py_charset = charset
```

(my database charset = latin1, but data inserted in koi8-r).

Then 
```python
con = mdb.connect('localhost', 'user', 'passwd', 'billing');
cur = con.cursor()
cur.execute("SELECT fio FROM user WHERE id = %s", (36888,))
fio = cur.fetchone()
print(fio)
```

And I get normal data in KOI8-R

But when I updated mysqlclient to 1.4.X my "fix" stopped working. What changed from 1.3.X to 1.4.0 about encodings? My `py_charset = 'koi8-r'` is now ignored

Now I should additionally decode or encode/decode data:

```python
# above code
... 

# if use_unicode = False:
fio[0].decode('koi8-r')
# if use_unicode = True
fio[0].encode('latin1').decode('koi8-r')
```

but before I simply made the query and received data in KOI8-R  from mysql
Where should I look in your library to fix this again and get data without following decoding and encoding?

items.title: Returned Type from Query is always string
items.body:
Hi, 
I am currently investigating a Bug I encountered on the Django project. I have raised it, but we would like to know if it is possible to fix it on the mysqlclient side. 

**The problem arises on the given table:**
```
id char(32) COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci NOT NULL,
created_on datetime(6) NOT NULL,
expiry_date datetime(6) DEFAULT NULL
```

**And you use the following query** 
```
SELECT
    `advertisement_project`.`created_on`,
MIN(CASE
        WHEN
            (`buyout_buyout`.`is_archived` = 0
                AND `buyout_buyout`.`is_deleted` = 0)
        THEN
            `buyout_buyout`.`expiry_date`
        ELSE NULL
    END) AS `minExpiryDate`
FROM MyTable
GROUP BY `id`
```

Mysql Client returns the following row: 
[datetime(2016,1,1...), '2016-01-01 00:00:00'] 

The problem is that this custom column(minExpiryDate) is returned of type string. Our question is:



> I also wonder if it could be possible to let mysqlclient know what the expected type is for a specific cursor instead though. We have this information in the compiler (through .output_field) so if we can provide per-cursor converter hints I assume it would be even more efficient because it would be performed in C. Another option is figuring out if mysqlclient can somehow figure out how to introspect such return value on it's own (e.g. maybe MySQL returns a different field type in this case).



Django Bug: https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/30224
mysqlclient: version 1.4.2

Thanks,
Martin

items.title: cursor.executemany doesn't work when functions are used
items.body:
Thanks for maintaining and supporting such a crucial library.

I ran into a scenario where it wasn't very obvious why executemany's performance was not up to the mark. It seems the regex RE_INSERT_VALUES doesn't support queries where mysql functions are being called in the VALUES clause.

Usecase to support queries of the form:

```sql
INSERT INTO testdb.test (type, some_field, status, some_char_field) VALUES (%s, hex(%s), %s, md5(%s));
```

MySQL supports this query pattern and it isn't very helpful when mysqlclient-python silently falls back to cursor.execute and performance drops.
A 'warning' level log here will go a long way to help developers unearth reasons for those performance hits.

I also tried to come up with a regex to support this query pattern. Looking for comments/feedback if it's missing anything.

```python
RE_INSERT_VALUES = re.compile(
    r"\s*((?:INSERT|REPLACE)\b.+\bVALUES?\s*)" +
    r"(\(\s*(?:(?:[a-zA-Z0-9]+?[(])?%s(?:[)])?|(?:[a-zA-Z0-9]+?[(])?%\(.+\)s(?:[)])?)\s*(?:,\s*(?:(?:[a-zA-Z0-9]+?[(])?%s(?:[)])?|(?:[a-zA-Z0-9]+?[(])?%\(.+\)s(?:[)])?)\s*)*\))" +
    r"(\s*(?:ON DUPLICATE.*)?);?\s*\Z",
    re.IGNORECASE | re.DOTALL)
```

Thanks.

items.title: Error code 2006 raised for invalid password instead of 1045
items.body:
When connecting to MySQL with an invalid password, up until version 1.3.13 the following exception is raised by mysqlclient-python:

`_mysql_exceptions.OperationalError: (1045, "Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)")`

with version 1.3.14 and 1.4.0rc1 the following exception is raised instead:

`_mysql_exceptions.OperationalError: (2006, "Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)")`

Note the MySQL error code is now **2006** (normally representing "server has gone away") instead of code **1045** (Access denied).



This can easily be seen with the following python code:
```
import MySQLdb
MySQLdb.connect(host="127.0.0.1",user="root",passwd="wrong")
```

Tested on Ubuntu 16.04 with Python 2.7.12 and MySQL 5.7.24


Example session
```
root@myhost:/tmp# cat my.py
import MySQLdb
MySQLdb.connect(host="127.0.0.1",user="root",passwd="wrong")

root@myhost:/tmp# pip list | grep mysql
mysqlclient                   1.3.14

root@myhost:/tmp# mysql -u root --password=wrong -h 127.0.0.1
mysql: [Warning] Using a password on the command line interface can be insecure.
ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)

root@myhost:/tmp# python my.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "my.py", line 2, in <module>
    MySQLdb.connect(host="127.0.0.1",user="root",passwd="wrong")
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/MySQLdb/__init__.py", line 85, in Connect
    return Connection(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/MySQLdb/connections.py", line 208, in __init__
    super(Connection, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs2)
_mysql_exceptions.OperationalError: (2006, "Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)")

root@myhost:/tmp# pip uninstall mysqlclient
Uninstalling mysqlclient-1.3.14:
<snip>
root@myhost:/tmp# pip install mysqlclient==1.3.13
<snip>
Successfully installed mysqlclient-1.3.13

root@myhost:/tmp# mysql -u root --password=wrong -h 127.0.0.1
mysql: [Warning] Using a password on the command line interface can be insecure.
ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)

root@myhost:/tmp# python my.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "my.py", line 2, in <module>
    MySQLdb.connect(host="127.0.0.1",user="root",passwd="wrong")
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/MySQLdb/__init__.py", line 85, in Connect
    return Connection(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/MySQLdb/connections.py", line 204, in __init__
    super(Connection, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs2)
_mysql_exceptions.OperationalError: (1045, "Access denied for user 'root'@'127.0.0.1' (using password: YES)")
```

items.title: Test failures after upgrading Django app to mysqlclient 1.3.14
items.body:
Hi 

### STR:
1. Have a Django 1.11 app whose tests make use of [CaptureQueriesContext](https://github.com/django/django/blob/1.11.17/django/test/utils.py#L621-L654), such as:
    - https://github.com/mozilla/treeherder/blob/d36bb8ab7644d3afe4b21e2b283c77e51aca1a15/tests/model/test_bugscache.py#L151-L179
2. Upgrade the `mysqlclient` used by that app from 1.3.13 to 1.3.14, eg:

3. Run test suite (either locally or on Travis)

### Expected:
No test failures after upgrading, since:
- it was a minor release
- there was no mention of removing `_last_executed` in the changelog

### Actual:
Test failures, eg:

```
        with CaptureQueriesContext(connection) as context:
```

If restoring `_last_executed` ends up being wontfix, please can the changelog be updated to mention the removal (and if possible a reference to say Django <2.1 users should not update)?

Many thanks :-)

Refs:
- https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/pull/283#issuecomment-444562762
- https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/30013
- django/django/pull/10726
- django/django/pull/10727

items.title: Memory leak in cursor exception handler
items.body:
Exception catch block in execute() method of BaseCursor is reading exception info using sys.exc_info() and it looks like it is keeping reference to call stack even if it is used properly.
I'm talking about following line: https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/master/MySQLdb/cursors.py#L254
Even if it is implemented as proposed in python documentation (return only first 2 values of tuple: https://docs.python.org/2/library/sys.html#sys.exc_info) problem still exists.

It is very hard to notice this with small call stack so I did it using Django app.
- Python 2.7.10
- Django 1.11.9

Steps:
1. Create new Django app
2. Create basic model (myapp.models):
```
from django.db import models

class MemoryLeakModel(models.Model):
    field1 = models.CharField(max_length=128)
    field2 = models.CharField(max_length=128)
```
3. Create management command that will create leak (it is easier with management command), memory_leak.py:
```
import django.core.management.base
import myapp.models

class Command(django.core.management.base.BaseCommand):

    def handle(self, *args, **options):
        print "clear prev data"
        myapp.models.MemoryLeakModel.objects.all().delete()
        print "start"
        i = 0
        while True:
            i += 1
            try:
                myapp.models.MemoryLeakModel(field1="x"*129, field2="leak").save()
            except Exception as e:
                print 'Fail: %s' % i
```
4. Run htop to look at your process memory (i.e. filter by "python manage.py memory_leak")
5. Run management command, i.e. `python manage.py memory_leak`

In my tests, process was leaking 1MB per ~2500 exceptions.

I know that this is very rare scenario and that in regular situation something else is wrong in case you are getting in this, but some of my scripts sometimes get in this situation and I want them continue working until I can react, instead be killed by supervisor.

Solution:
Proper solution would be to use exception instance instead of getting instance class from sys. I think that all needed information is already there.
So I suggest changing following lines:
```
        try:
            res = self._query(query)
        except Exception:
            exc, value = sys.exc_info()[:2]
            self.errorhandler(self, exc, value)
```
Into this:
```
        try:
            res = self._query(query)
        except Exception as exc:
            self.errorhandler(self, exc.__class__, exc)
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./x", line 5, in <module>
    db=_mysql.connect(db="mydb", host="remote.example.com", user="user", passwd="password") _mysql_exceptions.OperationalError: (2059, 'Plugin mysql_clear_password could not be loaded: Error loading shared library lib/mariadb/plugin/mysql_clear_password.so: No such file or directory')
```
the lib exists at
```
@a63e69f065a7:/usr$ ls -la /usr/lib/mariadb/plugin/mysql_clear_password.so
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root          5888 Jun 12 13:24 /usr/lib/mariadb/plugin/mysql_clear_password.so
```

As it seems from the error message it tries to load from `lib/mariadb/plugin/mysql_clear_password.so`
This looked a relative path for me so the interesting finding is that if you cd to /usr before run the script it works.

```
cd /usr
@a63e69f065a7:/usr$ /x
@a63e69f065a7:/usr$
``` 
(empty output means it's ok)

Do you have any idea what could set the path wrong and how to fix it?

Thanks for the help in advance

items.title: Signal sent while query is in progress will freeze process.
items.body:
First, my respects and congratulations for keeping this project alive!
I apologize in advance if this issue is actually related to the underlying C library.

My colleague @octava25 and I have identified and reproduced an old and hard-to-track issue with our production servers:
Randomly, after receiving a signal used to reload configuration files, our processes would block, forcing us to kill that interpreter process and restart it.

We have further identified this problem as coming from the MySQLdb package. 
In order to reproduce the bug, one has to:

1. In <Shell#1>, run the following code:
```
import MySQLdb
import signal

db_host = ""
db_user = ""
db_passwd = ""
db_name = ""

def sig_handler(signum, frame):
    print("In sig handler")


signal.signal(signal.SIGCONT, sig_handler)


def main():
    print("start")
    connection = MySQLdb.connect(host=db_host, user=db_user, passwd=db_passwd, db=db_name)
    connection.cursor().execute("SELECT SLEEP(15)")
    print("end")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

2. While the above code is executing, open <Shell#2> and send `SIGCONT` to the Python process started in <Shell#1>. We have tested `SIGHUP` and `SIGUSR1` with the same results.
3. Notice that the process started in <Shell#1> will never finish.


**Weirdly, the above behavior can not be reproduced if a signal handler isn't added.**

items.title: Problem building from source against MariaDB 10.2.11
items.body:
I am building mysqlclient 1.3.13 from source against Python 3.6.3 and MariaDB 10.2.11.

It fails to build with an error about libNone.a.

I tracked this down to `client` not being set properly in `setup_posix.py`

Here's a patch which fixes it. If you'd prefer this as a PR then I'm happy to make one, but I wanted to check that I wasn't doing anything silly first...
```
--- setup_posix.py.orig 2018-06-27 12:17:09.000000000 +0100
+++ setup_posix.py      2018-08-29 15:15:21.941166016 +0100
@@ -75,13 +75,18 @@
 
     # properly handle mysql client libraries that are not called libmysqlclient
     client = None
-    CLIENT_LIST = ['mysqlclient', 'mysqlclient_r', 'mysqld',
+    CLIENT_LIST = ['mysqlclient', 'mysqlclient_r', 'mysqld', 'mariadb',
                    'perconaserverclient', 'perconaserverclient_r']
     for c in CLIENT_LIST:
         if c in libraries:
             client = c
             break
 
+    if client == 'mariadb':
+        client = 'mariadbclient'
+    if client is None:
+        raise ValueError("Couldn't identify mysql client library")
+
     if static:
         extra_objects.append(os.path.join(library_dirs[0], 'lib%s.a' % client))
         if client in libraries:

```

Example code:

```python

c.fetchall()
```

Causes an error like:

```qml
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/var/task/handler.py", line 50, in hello

File "/var/task/MySQLdb/cursors.py", line 250, in execute
```

items.title: Add optional parameter 'ignore', 'replace' or 'backslashreplace' in string the decoding function
items.body:
I've found some issues with some records stored in a MySQL database.
At this line, an UnicodeDecodeError exception is raised when I'm fetching data from a specific table:

https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/3de469db63c5da47d61ac79bba5dadc0d22bde5c/MySQLdb/connections.py#L231

I know that the issue is caused by some malformed data store in MySQL that cannot be decoded as UTF-8 since they were incorrectly encoded in the first place.

But it would be nice if the driver has a better way to deal with these cases by simply adding an option in the connection defining the string decode configuration: 'strict',  'ignore', 'replace' or 'backslashreplace'.

So, basically I'm proposing to add the following option to the connection class.

        :param str decode_errors='strict':
            The default value is 'strict' but it can accept 'ignore' or 'replace' in PY2
            And in PY3 it can be also set as 'backslashreplace'

And the string_decoder implementation would be:

```python
def string_decoder(s):
    return s.decode(db.encoding, errors=decode_errors)
```

References:
- https://docs.python.org/2/howto/unicode.html
- https://docs.python.org/3/howto/unicode.html

items.title: LookupError: unknown encoding: koi8r. Is possible to add that encoding?
items.body:
Hi.

Note: MySQL knows it as "koi8r", Python as "koi8-r" or "koi8_r". If I set charset='koi8-r' in database connection i get an error:

items.title: Publish self-contained wheel package on pypi.org
items.body:
It would be nice if we could just `pip install mysqlclient` without prior installation of the development libraries.

The naming of the required packages across different distros is inconsistent. This makes one to search for packages in case of some exotic distro like Alpine.

It also makes it difficult to use `mysqlclient` in a docker environment.

 `psycopg2` provides wheels, I suppose `mysqlclient` could do that too.

items.title: NULL C exception causes segfault in python
items.body:
It happens that when i tried connecting to a server refusing the connection, my python interpreter crashes when accessing the subsequent OperationalError arguments.
```
import MySQLdb
try:
    client = MySQLdb.connect('127.0.0.4')
except Exception as err:
    print(err)
    print(err.args[1])
```
This crashes after displaying the error as `(1130, <NULL>)`.

After investigating, it appears there is a case at the initialisation of the connection where the error raised can have a NULL argument, [in this part of the C code](https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/92cd53289376dbd1eff90a94b2810c4641205d5f/_mysql.c#L304).

I didn't have the time to investigate further what should be passed as argument to the error instanciation, but it breaks python quite hard.

items.title: OperationalError: (1054, "Unknown column 'inf' in 'field list'")
items.body:
# Steps to reproduce
1) Create a table like this:
```sql
CREATE TABLE `test` (
  `test` float DEFAULT NULL
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8mb4;
```
2) Try to insert a very large float number:
```python
import MySQLdb
db = MySQLdb.connect(user='test',passwd='test', db='test')
c = db.cursor()
c.execute('show tables')
c.execute('insert into `test` (`test`) VALUES (%s)', [2e2400])
```

# Expected behavior
Since MySQL can't represent infinity and this could result in unexpected data issues (imagine somebody had `inf` or `nan` columns), I think it should raise a more descriptive error message saying that infinity is not a valid value.

# Actual behavior:
Python exception:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
OperationalError                          Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-9-2f445a32ed23> in <module>()
      3 c = db.cursor()
      4 c.execute('show tables')
----> 5 c.execute('insert into `test` (`test`) VALUES (%s)', [2e2400])

.../.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/MySQLdb/cursors.pyc in execute(self, query, args)
    248         except Exception:
    249             exc, value = sys.exc_info()[:2]
--> 250             self.errorhandler(self, exc, value)
    251         self._executed = query
    252         if not self._defer_warnings:

.../.venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/MySQLdb/connections.pyc in defaulterrorhandler(***failed resolving arguments***)
     48     del connection
     49     if isinstance(errorvalue, BaseException):
---> 50         raise errorvalue
     51     if errorclass is not None:
     52         raise errorclass(errorvalue)

OperationalError: (1054, "Unknown column 'inf' in 'field list'")
```

Setting a breakpoint reveals that it's trying to run this query:
> 'insert into `test` (`test`) VALUES (inf)'

which is not valid, since MySQL doesn't know about `inf`.

# What's going on?
[`Float2Str`](https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/blob/92cd53289376dbd1eff90a94b2810c4641205d5f/MySQLdb/converters.py#L68-L69) receives `inf` (huge float) as value and tries to interpolate it using
```python
'%.15g' % o
```
which returns literally `inf`.

Not sure if that's something you'd like to fix here, but since it's producing an invalid MySQL query, I'd say it's a bug in this library.

How do you feel about checking for `inf`/`nan` and raising some kind of Exception?

Happy to submit a PR if we can agree on a good solution. :)

items.title: MySQL 8.0 support on Windows
items.body:
`mysqlclient.lib` uses OpenSSL.
We should use ssleay32.dll and libeay32.dll in `<MySQL 8 install dir>/bin`.

How can I create Windows binary wheel?  Copy these dll files,,, to where?

---

mysql-connector-python wheel installs `libeay32.dll`, `libmysql.dll` and `ssleay32.dll` under
`site-packages`.
We put `_mysql.<tag>.pyd` into `site-packages`.  If we bundle these dlls, mysqlclient conflicts
against mysql-connector-python.

If user installed both of mysqlclient and mysql-connector-python, and uninstall one, dlls are removed.

Maybe, we need to move `_mysql.pyd` into `MySQLdb` before next release?
